I can't tell you enough, this game gets addictive with its content and variety. A community that is strong and a development team that works on their game with a passion. This game is a must have if you are a fan of horror or enjoy asymmetrical multiplayer. I have many hours on my PSN account and finally got a computer to play this and stream it to share to other communities what this game is about.
It's a very good game especially if you had a bad day at work.

Juego que ha d√≠a de hoy (8 de marzo de 2020), no es nada recomendable, ya que:
-El tema de Killer y Survivor est√° desbalanceado a favor l√≥gicamente del superviviente, en los 2 primeros minutos de partida ya tienen hecho un generador de 5 que tienen que hacer, si tienes suerte claro, porque si no te das prisa en herir a todos y al menos a colgar a 1 olv√≠date de la partida, dala por perdida porque no te da tiempo a reaccionar
-El tema de Matchmaking --> Puedes ser tu rango 8 como asesino y en un partida encontrar como m√≠nimo 1 rango rojo (1-2-3-4), en todas las partidas que llevo en rangos 7 u 8 encuentro en todas las partidas un rango rojo
-Tema sobre los servidores dedicados--> Dicen que el remedio es peor que la enfermedad, pues as√≠ es, pusieron los servidores dedicados (Servidores que aportan los propias desarrolladores del juego) y desde entonces los hits de los asesinos a los supervivientes son demasiado falsos, puedes a ver saltado la venta y estar corriendo y llevarte un hit por culpa del lag que tienen los servidores
-A la hora de encontrar partida --> Cuando eres rango alto (Del 20 al 15, m√°s o menos ) puedes estar durante 5 minutos sin exagerar buscando partida, ya que no encuentra los jugadores de tu mismo rango

Desde mi opini√≥n el juego estaba muy bien antes de los servidores dedicados y sobretodo y m√°s importante, antes de nerfeo a una habilidad (Ruina) que era una habilidad la cu√°l atrasaba el rush de motores, desde entonces el juego no es disfrutable

It's an addicting and tilting game. Not one that I actually crave to play because it's fun, but because it holds it's clutches over me. I enjoy it when the stars align and I continue to let it torment me so that I can get that feeling of enjoyment that occasionally graces me with it's visage.

I have an unusual love/hate relationship with Dead by Daylight so far. In principle the game is great, it's a thematic, asymmetrical 1 vs 4 game with a wide variety of characters on both sides, including some popular IPs available as DLC like Freddy, Michael Meyers and Ash. The graphics are decent and the gameplay is smooth with relatively easy to understand controls. The Bloodweb level up system is interesting and the way you can customize your characters through perks and add-ons from it improves replayability.

At the same time, playing the game sometimes feels like a tedious game of hide and seek with a bit of tag mixed in. Running in a loop around a car or bales of hay, etc, with a pallet next to it 10 times a game is frankly kind of boring. And as a killer nothing is more frustrating than either not finding the survivors for an extended period or trying to catch a survivor in an extended chase through a longer loop.  

Also some of the killers have controls which make them a bit unfun to learn to play. Nurse's teleportation is potentially very strong, but looking at the ground and wheezing after every single teleport every few seconds of play gets really, REALLY annoying, even if you are doing well with her. Trapper's traps are cool in principle but require him to walk out and pick them up off the ground from random spots and are often a bit easy for the survivors to spot or avoid or sabotage and, even though it doesn't happen often, the fact that he can accidentally sometimes step on his own trap just adds insult to injury. Billy's chainsaw is strong but charging up and steering is very difficult to learn.  Wraith has a cool cloaking ability but takes a frustrating two seconds to pop in and out of it every single time. 

Some of the DLC characters wisely did away with these "your power is cool but have an annoying handicap" design - Ghostface for instance has stealth which he can instantly go into and which instantly ends on an attack but which isn't as "invisible" or quick moving as Wraith's, maintaining character balance but without that annoying pause. Hag and Freddy can both place traps which aren't as directly injurious as Trappers but which they can place pretty much at will as often as they like and which are a bit harder for the survivors to avoid setting off. And Oni, when fully charged up, rushes around like Billy but with much better steering and control, with the downside being they can't start the power up whenever they like. So it does feel like, over time, the developers have been getting away from some of the old philosophy of "powerful with a pause every time" to more of a "not quite as powerful but use it at will or with full control" thinking which is good.

And while I'm on the subject of DLC, the game does offer a wide variety of cosmetic DLC in an in-game store. I have no interest in any of it personally but hey, some people like that stuff. :)  What's a bit more confusing is that the game has at least three or four different "currencies" to buy things and it's not exactly clear to a new player what buys what or how you get them. Bloodpoints you earn for free every match and from daily missions and are used to buy your perks and add-ons. But then there are at least two other currencies, one you earn in game and one "gold" currency you purchase with cash, which are both used for different somewhat overlapping sets of DLC items. You can save up the "in-game" currency to unlock some of the DLC characters, for example, or buy them outright, but other DLC characters (mainly the IP related ones like Freddy) can only be purchased with cash "gold". Unlocking certain "teachable" perks from one character to use with all your characters use the in-game only currency, and some cosmetics can be bought with in-game currency while others require cash. It's kind of a confusing mess of a store model.


All that being said, I think overall Dead by Daylight is a "good enough" game to recommend trying if the theme and idea behind it sounds fun. I'd put it in the category of "wait for a sale or free weekend and give it a try", but either way I think this is worth giving a look, especially if you're a horror movie fan. As of this review (March 2020) the game is still releasing new killers and content and queue times are still reasonable so the game is far from "dead". Just be aware that there is a bit of a learning curve for certain killers and maybe check out some gameplay videos to get a sense of how the game plays and what characters you want to play before diving in to the deep end.

Killers camp and as a result players try to infinite loop the killers so they don't get caught. It's a vicious cycle that has gotten out of control lately. Most games just come out to who can be the most toxic towards each other. With survivors teabagging and killers taunting each other. The whole horror element is stripped and the fun is just not there anymore.
